meta.title: How Emotionally Intelligent Is Your Child?
meta.description: A research-based assessment of your child's emotional intelligence across four key domains: self-awareness, emotional regulation, empathy, and social navigation. Find out where they're thriving and where targeted support can help.
meta.intro: This quiz measures your child's ability to recognize, understand, and manage emotions — both their own and others'. Emotional intelligence isn't fixed. It's a set of learnable skills that predict well-being more than IQ.
meta.subject: your child
meta.shareCta: Curious about your own child's emotional intelligence?
sources: Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence research

previewCta.title: Get your child's complete emotional intelligence profile
previewCta.body: See how your child's EQ breaks down across self-awareness, regulation, empathy, and social skills. Find out what's strong, what's developing, and where small shifts make the biggest difference.

previewPromises: What each domain score means for your child
Your child's strongest emotional skills to celebrate
Targeted next steps for developing areas
A prioritized action plan you can start today

communityCta.title: Get scripts and routines from parents raising emotionally smart kids
communityCta.body: Real strategies for teaching feelings, managing meltdowns, and building empathy — from parents in the thick of it. We are there with you daily too.

questions.text: When your child is upset, can they name what they're feeling?
questions.subtext: Not in a meltdown moment. When you ask later or when the emotion is medium-sized.

options.text: Yes — they can usually identify specific emotions like frustrated, disappointed, or worried
Sometimes — they can name big ones like mad or sad, but struggle with more nuanced feelings
Not really — it's all 'bad' or 'fine', or they can't articulate what's happening inside

questions.text: Does your child notice when their body is sending signals (hungry, tired, overwhelmed)?
questions.subtext: Can they connect the dots between 'I feel weird' and 'I skipped lunch' or 'I'm exhausted'?

options.text: Often — they'll say 'I'm grumpy because I'm tired' or notice their own patterns
Sometimes — with prompting they can recognize it, but don't always notice on their own
Rarely — they melt down or act out without connecting it to hunger, fatigue, or overstimulation

questions.text: Can your child tell you what makes them feel better when they're upset?
questions.subtext: Do they have a sense of what helps — a hug, alone time, moving their body, talking it out?

options.text: Yes — they know what they need and can usually ask for it or do it themselves
Emerging — they're starting to figure it out but need help identifying or naming it
Not yet — they don't have strategies or can't articulate what would help

questions.text: When your child is frustrated or angry, how do they handle it?
questions.subtext: In an everyday frustration — not a full meltdown. Something didn't work, a plan changed, a sibling took their toy.

options.text: They can usually pause, use words, or take a break without escalating to hitting or screaming
It's 50/50 — sometimes they manage, sometimes they lose it depending on how full their tank is
They go from zero to explosion — hitting, throwing, screaming, or total shutdown

questions.text: After a big emotion, how quickly do they recover?
questions.subtext: Once the storm passes, can they move on or do they stay dysregulated for a long time?

options.text: Pretty quickly — they calm down within a few minutes and can re-engage with what's next
Takes a while — they need 15-30 minutes or some help from you to reset
They stay stuck — the mood lingers for hours or they cycle back into upset repeatedly

questions.text: Can your child delay gratification when something matters to them?
questions.subtext: Wait for dessert until after dinner, save a treat for later, finish homework before playing.

options.text: Usually — they can wait for things they care about without constant reminders or meltdowns
With support — they can do it if you help them hold the boundary or remind them why
Rarely — waiting feels impossible and they fall apart or sneak around the rule

questions.text: When someone else is upset, does your child notice?
questions.subtext: A crying sibling, a sad friend, you having a hard day — do they pick up on it?

options.text: Yes — they notice and often respond with concern, questions, or trying to help
Sometimes — they notice big displays of emotion but might miss subtler cues
Not really — they're so focused on their own experience they don't register others' feelings

questions.text: Can your child imagine how someone else might feel in a situation different from their own experience?
questions.subtext: Not just 'I'd be sad if that happened to me' — can they get that someone else might feel differently?

options.text: Increasingly — they're starting to grasp that other people have different feelings and perspectives
Emerging — they understand it in theory when you explain, but don't apply it spontaneously yet
Not yet — they assume everyone feels what they'd feel or struggle to imagine other viewpoints

questions.text: When your child has a conflict with a peer, what happens?
questions.subtext: A toy dispute, a disagreement about a game, someone cut in line — how do they handle it?

options.text: They can usually work it out — use words, compromise, or ask for help without it escalating
It's hit or miss — sometimes they manage, sometimes they shut down or get aggressive
They consistently struggle — either melting down, hitting, or withdrawing entirely

questions.text: Does your child have at least one reciprocal friendship?
questions.subtext: Not just parallel play or being tolerated — a peer they seek out, who seeks them out, who they actually play with (not at).

options.text: Yes — they have at least one friend where the relationship feels mutual and genuine
Sort of — they have kids they play with, but it's not quite reciprocal or it's fragile
Not really — friendships don't stick, or they struggle to connect with peers in a sustained way

high.headline: Knows what they feel
high.detail: Your child can name emotions beyond mad and sad, notice when their body is sending signals, and starting to build a vocabulary for their inner experience. That's the foundation for everything else in emotional intelligence.
high.strength: They're developing the metacognitive skill of observing their own emotions. This is the precursor to managing them — you can't regulate what you can't recognize.

medium.headline: Building the vocabulary
medium.detail: Your child can identify big emotions but struggles with nuance. They're starting to connect body signals to feelings with your help, but don't reliably do it on their own yet. This is developmentally normal and highly teachable.
medium.concern: Label emotions out loud as you notice them — in yourself, in them, in characters. 'You look frustrated' or 'I'm feeling overwhelmed right now.' The vocabulary grows through exposure and practice.

low.headline: Emotions are still a fog
low.detail: Your child doesn't yet have the language or awareness to name what's happening inside them. Feelings hit like weather — sudden, overwhelming, and without warning. This is a skill gap, not a personality trait.
low.concern: Start with the basics: mad, sad, scared, happy. Point them out in real time — 'That's frustration' when they're stuck on a puzzle. Co-regulation first, then labeling. They'll build the map over time.

high.headline: Can ride the wave
high.detail: Your child has strategies for managing big feelings. They can pause, use words, take a break, or ask for help before completely losing it. Recovery time is reasonable. This is one of the strongest predictors of long-term well-being.
high.strength: They're building the neural pathways for self-regulation — the ability to feel something hard and not let it take over. This skill compounds over time and generalizes to everything from friendships to frustration tolerance.

medium.headline: Strategies are hit or miss
medium.detail: Your child can regulate when their tank is full, but falls apart when tired, hungry, or overstimulated. They're learning, but the skills aren't automatic yet. It's inconsistent, which is normal for this stage of development.
medium.concern: Co-regulate first — they can't learn regulation skills while dysregulated. Once calm, practice strategies during neutral moments: deep breaths, counting, taking space. The goal isn't perfection, it's slightly better than last month.

low.headline: Zero to meltdown fast
low.detail: Your child goes from fine to explosion with little middle ground. They don't have reliable strategies yet for pausing or calming down, and recovery takes a long time. Regulation is the skill they need most, and it's also the hardest to teach mid-crisis.
low.concern: Build the foundation outside of meltdowns: practice calming strategies when things are calm, work on body awareness, model your own regulation out loud. When they're escalated, your job is co-regulation — not teaching. The learning happens later.

high.headline: Notices others' feelings
high.detail: Your child is tuned into the emotional states of people around them. They notice when someone is upset, ask questions, or try to help. They're starting to grasp that other people's feelings might be different from their own. This is advanced for their age.
high.strength: Empathy at this level is both a gift and something to protect. Kids who are emotionally attuned can take on others' feelings too much — help them distinguish between noticing and absorbing.

medium.headline: Empathy is emerging
medium.detail: Your child notices big emotional displays but might miss subtler cues. They're starting to understand that people feel differently than they do, but it's not automatic yet. With prompting, they can step into someone else's shoes — they just don't always do it spontaneously.
medium.concern: Point out others' emotions as you notice them: 'Your brother looks frustrated,' 'I wonder how she felt when that happened.' Ask perspective-taking questions: 'How do you think he feels?' The skill develops through guided practice.

low.headline: Still very self-focused
low.detail: Your child is developmentally centered on their own experience and doesn't reliably notice or respond to others' emotions yet. This is common in younger kids or those who are emotionally overwhelmed themselves. Empathy develops later when self-awareness is stronger.
low.concern: You can't teach empathy while they're dysregulated or egocentric. Focus first on helping them understand their own feelings. Empathy grows from a stable foundation of self-awareness — once they know what they feel, they can start to recognize it in others.

high.headline: Can work it out
high.detail: Your child has the skills to navigate peer conflicts without constant adult intervention. They can compromise, use words, or ask for help when stuck. They have at least one real friendship where the relationship feels mutual. These are the building blocks of social competence.
high.strength: The ability to manage conflict and maintain friendships is one of the strongest predictors of long-term happiness. Your child is developing resilience in relationships — the capacity to repair, negotiate, and stay connected even when things are hard.

medium.headline: Social skills are uneven
medium.detail: Your child can handle peer interactions when conditions are right, but struggles when tired, overstimulated, or in unfamiliar social settings. Friendships exist but might be fragile or one-sided. The skills are emerging but not yet reliable.
medium.concern: Coach conflicts after the fact, not during. Ask 'What could you try next time?' rather than lecturing. Set up one-on-one playdates with a preferred peer to build relational skills in a lower-stakes setting than group dynamics.

low.headline: Peer stuff is hard
low.detail: Your child struggles to navigate peer relationships. Conflicts escalate quickly, friendships don't stick, or they withdraw when things get tricky. This might be developmental, temperamental, or a sign they need more support building social skills.
low.concern: Social skills are teachable — they're just not intuitive for every kid. Break it down: practice greetings, turn-taking, joining play, handling 'no.' Role-play at home. Consider whether sensory, anxiety, or language issues are underneath the social struggles.

high-eq.headline: Emotionally Sharp
high-eq.subheadline: Your child is developing emotional intelligence at a level that's ahead of many peers — they're aware of their feelings, can manage them more often than not, and are starting to navigate the social world with real skill.
high-eq.explanation: A high EQ doesn't mean they never melt down or act like a jerk to their sibling. It means they have the building blocks: they can name feelings, recover from upsets, notice when someone else is struggling, and work through conflicts without constant adult rescue. These skills compound over time — emotionally intelligent kids become emotionally intelligent adults, and the research is clear that EQ predicts well-being better than IQ.
nextSteps: Keep building the vocabulary — introduce more nuanced feeling words like disappointed, overwhelmed, proud, jealous
Let them practice conflict resolution without jumping in to fix it — coach from the sidelines, don't referee every dispute
Model your own emotional awareness out loud: 'I'm feeling frustrated because the plan changed. I'm going to take a breath before I decide what to do.'
Protect their empathy — emotionally attuned kids can take on too much. Teach them the difference between noticing someone's feelings and being responsible for fixing them.
high-eq.watchOutFor: High-EQ kids sometimes become the emotional caretakers in peer groups or sibling dynamics. Watch for signs they're managing everyone else's feelings at the expense of their own. Empathy is a strength when it's balanced, a burden when it's unprotected.
high-eq.encouragement: Your child is developing a set of skills that will serve them for life. The ability to recognize, understand, and manage emotions is more predictive of success and happiness than academic performance. Keep doing what you're doing — you're giving them a real advantage.
high-eq.comparativeContext: Research on social-emotional learning shows that children with strong emotional regulation and empathy skills have significantly better peer relationships, academic outcomes, and mental health in adolescence and adulthood.

developing-eq.headline: Building the Skills
developing-eq.subheadline: Your child is developing emotional intelligence, but it's uneven — some skills are emerging while others are still shaky. This is exactly where most kids are, and the good news is that EQ is highly teachable.
developing-eq.explanation: A mid-range EQ score means your child has some of the building blocks but not all of them, or they can use the skills sometimes but not consistently. Maybe they can name feelings but can't regulate them yet. Or they notice when others are upset but struggle to manage peer conflicts. The gaps are normal, and they're also the roadmap for what to work on next. Emotional intelligence isn't innate — it's a set of learnable skills that develop through practice, coaching, and maturation.
nextSteps: Look at your domain breakdown and find the one scoring lowest — that's your highest-leverage target for the next few months
Label emotions in real time — not just theirs, but yours, characters in books, people you see. The vocabulary grows through exposure.
Co-regulate first, teach later — when they're upset, your job is to help them calm down, not to lecture about better choices. The learning happens after recovery.
Practice calming strategies during neutral moments — deep breaths, counting, taking space. These don't work mid-meltdown if they've never been practiced when calm.
Set up one-on-one playdates with a preferred peer to build social skills in a lower-stakes setting than group dynamics
developing-eq.watchOutFor: It's easy to focus on the meltdowns and miss the progress. Notice when they do use a skill — even partially. 'You were really frustrated but you used your words instead of hitting' is the kind of feedback that builds the skill faster than criticism.
developing-eq.encouragement: Emotional intelligence develops on a longer timeline than academic skills, and it's lumpier — kids make progress, then regress under stress, then consolidate the skill later. You're not behind. You're in the middle of the process.
developing-eq.comparativeContext: Most children in this age range are actively developing emotional regulation and empathy skills. Targeted practice in the lowest-scoring domain produces measurable gains within 2-3 months, according to social-emotional learning research.

emerging-eq.headline: Early Stages
emerging-eq.subheadline: Your child is at the beginning of developing emotional intelligence. The skills are emerging, but they're not reliable yet — and that's not a character flaw, it's a developmental stage.
emerging-eq.explanation: A low EQ score doesn't mean your child is destined to struggle socially or emotionally. It means they're early in the process of learning how to recognize, name, and manage feelings — both their own and others'. Some kids are slower to develop these skills due to temperament, sensory sensitivities, language delays, or just developmental timing. The critical thing to understand is that emotional intelligence is trainable. It's not fixed. But it requires direct teaching, consistent modeling, and a lot of co-regulation before they can self-regulate.
nextSteps: Start with self-awareness: label emotions out loud when you see them — 'That's frustration,' 'This is disappointment.' Build the vocabulary first.
Co-regulate during big feelings: your calm presence is the scaffold they need to learn regulation. Sit with them, breathe with them, don't lecture.
Practice calming strategies when they're already calm — not during a meltdown. Deep breaths, counting, using words, taking space. Rehearse when the stakes are low.
Read books about feelings, point out emotions in characters, ask 'How do you think they felt?' to build empathy and perspective-taking.
If social struggles are persistent, consider whether there are underlying issues — sensory processing, anxiety, language delays — that need support beyond just EQ coaching.
Work with their teacher or a counselor if these patterns are causing significant problems at school or in peer relationships.
emerging-eq.watchOutFor: When emotional skills are this early, the temptation is to punish the behavior — time-outs for hitting, consequences for meltdowns. But you can't punish a skill gap into existence. Consequences might be necessary for safety, but they won't teach regulation. Co-regulation, modeling, and practice will.
emerging-eq.encouragement: Emotional intelligence develops over years, not months. The fact that your child is behind their peers right now doesn't predict where they'll be at 10, 15, or 25. Focus on one skill at a time, celebrate tiny progress, and don't compare them to siblings or classmates. Their timeline is their own.
emerging-eq.comparativeContext: Research shows that children who receive consistent coaching in emotional awareness and regulation show significant skill growth within 6-12 months, even when starting from a low baseline. Early intervention matters, and these skills are highly responsive to practice.
